item.title: Linking python with PostGIS
item.description: GIS databases are sort of a necessary evil. Once your data gets too big for RAM you’ve got to start thinking either about relational databases or doing something fancy with dask. PostGIS is a spatial database extender for PostgreSQL object-relational database. In essence, PostGIS puts GIS functions into SQL queries allowing you to run queries and joins based on location. PostgreSQL is big nasty and powerful so this post provides a basic look at utilising PostGIS for the ‘GIS stuff’ and linking python to a PostGIS database for pre-processing and visualisation.

item.title: About
item.description: I made a single.html in ./themes/mytheme/layouts/mylayout/single.html I am getting a 404 error. Any help would be appreciated.

item.title: Estimating CDFs from data done right
item.description: This post looks at estimating empirical cumulative density functions (CDFs) and their confidence intervals from data.

item.title: Confidence intervals for LOWESS models in python
item.description: LOWESS (or also referred to as LOESS for locally-weighted scatterplot smoothing) is a non-parametric regression method for smoothing data. But how do we get uncertainties on the curve?

item.title: Fast and easy gridding of point data with geopandas
item.description: This post looks at using the geopandas library to do fast efficient gridding of point data onto a regular grid.

item.title: Visualising 2 billion pixel rasters with datashader and xarray
item.description: This post looks at visualising large raster datasets with Datashader and xarray.

item.title: Essential packages for geospatial analysis in python
item.description: Python is fast becoming the defacto standard for geospatial work – primarily because of its great ecosystem of packages, but also probably whatever you want to do someone has posted an answer for it on stackoverflow with attached python code. To save you some of that trouble below is a collection of “essential”” packages for everything geospatial in python.

item.title: ASCII maps of vector files
item.description:
ʕ•ᴥ•ʔ

I recently came across a nice python package for visualising vector data quickly. Of course, an obvious option is to fire up QGIS but often I generate these on a remote server so would like something a little more “text-based”… Then this post highlighted some rather charming tools for generating ASCII rasterisations of vector geometries. I liked the look of the python-based gj2ascii the most.
